description:
Pyxicephalus adspersus, commonly known as the African bullfrog, is a species of frog native to sub-Saharan Africa. It belongs to the family Pyxicephalidae.

The African bullfrog is a large, robust amphibian, typically reaching lengths of up to 20 centimeters (8 inches) from snout to vent. It has a broad, flattened head and a stocky, muscular body. The skin is warty and can range in color from olive-green to brown, with darker spots or blotches. The eyes are large and prominent, and the toes are partially webbed, adaptations for its semi-aquatic lifestyle.

These frogs are primarily nocturnal and inhabit a variety of habitats, including savannas, grasslands, and temporary ponds and pools. They are opportunistic predators, feeding on a range of prey, including insects, small rodents, and even other amphibians. During the dry season, they may aestivate (a state of dormancy) to conserve water and energy.

The African bullfrog is known for its loud, deep-pitched call, which can be heard during the breeding season. Reproduction typically occurs during the rainy season, when the males gather in temporary water bodies and engage in territorial and mating behaviors. Females lay their eggs in the water, and the tadpoles undergo metamorphosis to transform into juvenile frogs.

This species is considered a relatively common and widespread amphibian within its native range, but it faces some threats, such as habitat loss and degradation due to human activities. Conservation efforts aim to maintain the species' populations and its important role in the ecosystems it inhabits.
